usage: See the manual page (man es) for a complete description of the commands. Type "help " for the documentation of . Available commands are: General commands help show this help exit, quit, q exit from the interactive shell trace, t enable/disable packet tracing verbose, v change verbosity level Connection establishment commands scan, s scan the network for easyshare servers connect connect to a remote server disconnect disconnect from a remote server open, o open a remote sharing (eventually discovering it) close, c close the remote sharing Transfer commands get, g get files and directories from the remote sharing put, p put files and directories in the remote sharing Local commands pwd show the name of current local working directory ls list local directory content l alias for ls -la tree list local directory contents in a tree-like format cd change local working directory mkdir create a local directory cp copy files and directories locally mv move files and directories locally rm remove files and directories locally exec, : execute an arbitrary command locally Remote commands rpwd show the name of current remote working directory rls list remote directory content rl alias for rls -la rtree list remote directory contents in a tree-like format rcd change remote working directory rmkdir create a remote directory rcp copy files and directories remotely rmv move files and directories remotely rrm remove files and directories remotely rexec, :: execute an arbitrary command remotely (disabled by default) since it will compromise server security Server information commands info, i show information about the remote server list list the sharings of the remote server ping test the connection with the remote server
help: COMMAND # alignment help - show the help of a command SYNOPSIS # alignment help [COMMAND] DESCRIPTION # alignment Show the help of COMMAND if specified, or show the list of commands if no COMMAND is given. Available commands are: : :: c cd close connect cp disconnect exec exit h help i info l list ls mkdir mv o open ping pwd q quit rcd rcp rexec rl rls rm rmkdir rmv rpwd rrm rtree s scan t trace tree v verbose
h: COMMAND # alignment help - show the help of a command SYNOPSIS # alignment help [COMMAND] DESCRIPTION # alignment Show the help of COMMAND if specified, or show the list of commands if no COMMAND is given. Available commands are: : :: c cd close connect cp disconnect exec exit h help i info l list ls mkdir mv o open ping pwd q quit rcd rcp rexec rl rls rm rmkdir rmv rpwd rrm rtree s scan t trace tree v verbose
exit: COMMAND # alignment exit - exit from the interactive shell SYNOPSIS # alignment exit quit q DESCRIPTION # alignment Exit from the interactive shell. Open connections are automatically closed.
quit: COMMAND # alignment exit - exit from the interactive shell SYNOPSIS # alignment exit quit q DESCRIPTION # alignment Exit from the interactive shell. Open connections are automatically closed.
q: COMMAND # alignment exit - exit from the interactive shell SYNOPSIS # alignment exit quit q DESCRIPTION # alignment Exit from the interactive shell. Open connections are automatically closed.
trace: COMMAND # alignment trace - enable/disable packet tracing SYNOPSIS # alignment trace [0 | 1] t [0 | 1] DESCRIPTION # alignment Show (1) or hide (0) the packets sent and received to and from the server for any operation. If no argument is given, toggle the packet tracing mode. EXAMPLES # alignment Usage example: /tmp t Tracing = 1 (enabled) /tmp o temp >> :12019 >> DISCOVER (58140) << 192.168.1.105:57300 << DISCOVER { "success": true, "data": { "name": "alice-arch", "sharings": [ { "name": "temp", "ftype": "dir", "read_only": false } ], "ssl": false, "auth": false, "ip": "192.168.1.105", "port": 12020, "discoverable": true, "discover_port": 12019 } } >> 192.168.1.105:12020 (stefano-arch) >> connect (password=None) << 192.168.1.105:12020 (stefano-arch) << connect { "success": true } >> 192.168.1.105:12020 (stefano-arch) >> open ("temp") << 192.168.1.105:12020 (stefano-arch) << open { "success": true, "data": "ebc40f8680d448dcad5c98291b720e37" } alice-arch.temp:/ - /tmp>
t: COMMAND # alignment trace - enable/disable packet tracing SYNOPSIS # alignment trace [0 | 1] t [0 | 1] DESCRIPTION # alignment Show (1) or hide (0) the packets sent and received to and from the server for any operation. If no argument is given, toggle the packet tracing mode. EXAMPLES # alignment Usage example: /tmp t Tracing = 1 (enabled) /tmp o temp >> :12019 >> DISCOVER (58140) << 192.168.1.105:57300 << DISCOVER { "success": true, "data": { "name": "alice-arch", "sharings": [ { "name": "temp", "ftype": "dir", "read_only": false } ], "ssl": false, "auth": false, "ip": "192.168.1.105", "port": 12020, "discoverable": true, "discover_port": 12019 } } >> 192.168.1.105:12020 (stefano-arch) >> connect (password=None) << 192.168.1.105:12020 (stefano-arch) << connect { "success": true } >> 192.168.1.105:12020 (stefano-arch) >> open ("temp") << 192.168.1.105:12020 (stefano-arch) << open { "success": true, "data": "ebc40f8680d448dcad5c98291b720e37" } alice-arch.temp:/ - /tmp>
verbose: COMMAND # alignment verbose - change verbosity level SYNOPSIS # alignment verbose [LEVEL/] v [LEVEL/] DESCRIPTION # alignment Change the verbosity level to LEVEL (default is 0, which is disabled). The messages are written to stdout. The allowed value of LEVEL are: 0 disabled (default) 1 errors 2 warnings 3 info 4 debug 5 internal libraries If no argument is given, increase the verbosity or resets it to 0 if it exceeds the maximum.
v: COMMAND # alignment verbose - change verbosity level SYNOPSIS # alignment verbose [LEVEL/] v [LEVEL/] DESCRIPTION # alignment Change the verbosity level to LEVEL (default is 0, which is disabled). The messages are written to stdout. The allowed value of LEVEL are: 0 disabled (default) 1 errors 2 warnings 3 info 4 debug 5 internal libraries If no argument is given, increase the verbosity or resets it to 0 if it exceeds the maximum.
pwd: COMMAND # alignment pwd - show the name of current local working directory SYNOPSIS # alignment pwd DESCRIPTION # alignment Show the name of current local working directory. The local working directory can be changed with the command cd. SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help rpwd" for the remote analogous.
ls: COMMAND # alignment ls - list local directory content SYNOPSIS # alignment ls [OPTION]... [DIR] DESCRIPTION # alignment List content of the local DIR or the current local directory if no DIR is specified. OPTIONS # alignment -a, --all show hidden files too -g, --group group by file type -l show more details -r, --reverse reverse sort order -s, --sort-size sort by size -S show files size SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help rls" for the remote analogous.
tree: COMMAND # alignment tree - list local directory contents in a tree-like format SYNOPSIS # alignment tree [OPTION]... [DIR] DESCRIPTION # alignment List recursively, in a tree-like format, the local DIR or the current local directory if no DIR is specified. OPTIONS # alignment -a, --all show hidden files too -d, --depth depth maximum display depth of tree -g, --group group by file type -l show more details -r, --reverse reverse sort order -s, --sort-size sort by size -S show files size SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help rtree" for the remote analogous.
cd: COMMAND # alignment cd - change local working directory SYNOPSIS # alignment cd [DIR] DESCRIPTION # alignment Change the current local working directory to DIR or to the user's home directory if DIR is not specified. SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help rcd" for the remote analogous.
mkdir: COMMAND # alignment mkdir - create a local directory SYNOPSIS # alignment mkdir DIR DESCRIPTION # alignment Create the local directory DIR. Parent directories of DIR are automatically created when needed. If DIR already exists, it does nothing. SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help rmkdir" for the remote analogous.
cp: COMMAND # alignment cp - copy files and directories locally SYNOPSIS # alignment cp SOURCE DEST cp SOURCE... DIR DESCRIPTION # alignment Copy local SOURCE file or directory to DEST, or copy multiple SOURCEs to the directory DIR. If used with two arguments as "cp SOURCE DEST" the following rules are applied: - If DEST doesn't exists, SOURCE will copied as DEST. - If DEST exists and it is a directory, SOURCE will be copied into DEST - If DEST exists and it is a file, SOURCE must be a file and it will overwrite DEST If used with at least arguments as "cp SOURCE... DIR" then DIR must be an existing directory and SOURCEs will be copied into it. SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help rcp" for the remote analogous.
mv: COMMAND # alignment mv - move files and directories locally SYNOPSIS # alignment mv SOURCE DEST mv SOURCE... DIR DESCRIPTION # alignment Move local SOURCE file or directory to DEST, or move multiple SOURCEs to the directory DIR. If used with two arguments as "mv SOURCE DEST" the following rules are applied: - If DEST doesn't exists, SOURCE will moved as DEST. - If DEST exists and it is a directory, SOURCE will be moved into DEST - If DEST exists and it is a file, SOURCE must be a file and it will overwrite DEST If used with at least arguments as "mv SOURCE... DIR" then DIR must be an existing directory and SOURCEs will be moved into it. SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help rmv" for the remote analogous.
rm: COMMAND # alignment rm - remove files and directories locally SYNOPSIS # alignment rm [FILE]... DESCRIPTION # alignment Remove local FILEs. If a FILE is a directory, it will be removed recursively. If a FILE does not exists, it will be ignored. This commands never prompts: essentially acts like unix's rm -rf. SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help rrm" for the remote analogous.
exec: COMMAND # alignment exec - execute an arbitrary command locally SYNOPSIS # alignment exec COMMAND : COMMAND :COMMAND DESCRIPTION # alignment Executes an arbitrary COMMAND locally. The COMMAND is executed via the shell and therefore allows all the shell features (e.g. variables, glob expansions, redirection). This might be useful for execute commands without exiting the easyshare's shell. The command can be run either with "exec COMMAND", ": COMMAND" or ":COMMAND". EXAMPLES # alignment Usage example: /tmp> ls f1 f2 /tmp> exec touch f3 f1 f2 f3 /tmp> : echo "hello" > f3 /tmp> :cat f3 hello SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help rexec" for the remote analogous.
:: COMMAND # alignment exec - execute an arbitrary command locally SYNOPSIS # alignment exec COMMAND : COMMAND :COMMAND DESCRIPTION # alignment Executes an arbitrary COMMAND locally. The COMMAND is executed via the shell and therefore allows all the shell features (e.g. variables, glob expansions, redirection). This might be useful for execute commands without exiting the easyshare's shell. The command can be run either with "exec COMMAND", ": COMMAND" or ":COMMAND". EXAMPLES # alignment Usage example: /tmp> ls f1 f2 /tmp> exec touch f3 f1 f2 f3 /tmp> : echo "hello" > f3 /tmp> :cat f3 hello SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help rexec" for the remote analogous.
rpwd: COMMAND # alignment rpwd - show the name of current remote working directory SYNOPSIS # alignment rpwd DESCRIPTION # alignment Show the name of current remote working directory. The remote working directory can be changed with the command rcd. SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help pwd" for the local analogous.
rls: COMMAND # alignment rls - list remote directory content SYNOPSIS # alignment rls [OPTION]... [DIR] rls [OPTION]... [SHARING_LOCATION] [DIR] SHARING_LOCATION must be specified if and only if not already connected to a remote sharing. In that case the connection will be established before execute the command, as "open SHARING_LOCATION" would do. Type "help open" for more information about SHARING_LOCATION format. DESCRIPTION # alignment List content of the remote DIR or the current remote directory if no DIR is specified. OPTIONS # alignment -a, --all show hidden files too -g, --group group by file type -l show more details -r, --reverse reverse sort order -s, --sort-size sort by size -S show files size SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help ls" for the local analogous.
rtree: COMMAND # alignment rtree - list remote directory contents in a tree-like format SYNOPSIS # alignment tree [OPTION]... [DIR] SHARING_LOCATION must be specified if and only if not already connected to a remote sharing. In that case the connection will be established before execute the command, as "open SHARING_LOCATION" would do. Type "help open" for more information about SHARING_LOCATION format. DESCRIPTION # alignment List recursively, in a tree-like format, the remote DIR or the current remote directory if no DIR is specified OPTIONS # alignment -a, --all show hidden files too -d, --depth depth maximum display depth of tree -g, --group group by file type -l show more details -r, --reverse reverse sort order -s, --sort-size sort by size -S show files size SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help tree" for the local analogous.
rcd: COMMAND # alignment rcd - change remote working directory SYNOPSIS # alignment rcd [DIR] DESCRIPTION # alignment Change the current remote working directory to DIR or to the root of the current sharing if no DIR is specified. EXAMPLES # alignment Usage example: /tmp> open music bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> rcd dir bob-debian.music:/dir - /tmp> rcd subdir bob-debian.music:/dir/subdir - /tmp> SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help cd" for the local analogous.
rmkdir: COMMAND # alignment rmkdir - create a remote directory SYNOPSIS # alignment rmkdir DIR rmkdir [SHARING_LOCATION] DIR SHARING_LOCATION must be specified if and only if not already connected to a remote sharing. In that case the connection will be established before execute the command, as "open SHARING_LOCATION" would do. Type "help open" for more information about SHARING_LOCATION format. DESCRIPTION # alignment Create the remote directory DIR. Parent directories of DIR are automatically created when needed. If DIR already exists, it does nothing. EXAMPLES # alignment Usage example: /tmp> open music bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> rmkdir newdir bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> rcd newdir bob-debian.music:/newdir - /tmp> SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help mkdir" for the local analogous.
rcp: COMMAND # alignment rcp - copy files and directories remotely SYNOPSIS # alignment rcp SOURCE DEST rcp SOURCE... DIR rcp [SHARING_LOCATION] SOURCE DEST rcp [SHARING_LOCATION] SOURCE... DIR SHARING_LOCATION must be specified if and only if not already connected to a remote sharing. In that case the connection will be established before execute the command, as "open SHARING_LOCATION" would do. Type "help open" for more information about SHARING_LOCATION format. DESCRIPTION # alignment Copy remote SOURCE file or directory to DEST, or copy multiple SOURCEs to the directory DIR. If used with two arguments as "rcp SOURCE DEST" the following rules are applied: - If DEST doesn't exists, SOURCE will copied as DEST. - If DEST exists and it is a directory, SOURCE will be copied into DEST - If DEST exists and it is a file, SOURCE must be a file and it will overwrite DEST If used with at least arguments as "rcp SOURCE... DIR" then DIR must be an existing directory and SOURCEs will be copied into it. EXAMPLES # alignment Usage example: /tmp> open music bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> rls f1 bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> rcp f1 f2 bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> rls f1 f2 /tmp> open music bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> rtree |-- dir |-- f1 +-- f2 bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> rcp f1 f2 dir bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> rtree dir |-- dir | |-- f1 | +-- f2 |-- f1 +-- f2 SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help cp" for the local analogous.
rmv: COMMAND # alignment rmv - move files and directories remotely SYNOPSIS # alignment rmv SOURCE DEST rmv SOURCE... DIR rmv [SHARING_LOCATION] SOURCE DEST rmv [SHARING_LOCATION] SOURCE... DIR SHARING_LOCATION must be specified if and only if not already connected to a remote sharing. In that case the connection will be established before execute the command, as "open SHARING_LOCATION" would do. Type "help open" for more information about SHARING_LOCATION format. DESCRIPTION # alignment Move remote SOURCE file or directory to DEST, or move multiple SOURCEs to the directory DIR. If used with two arguments as "rmv SOURCE DEST" the following rules are applied: - If DEST doesn't exists, SOURCE will moved as DEST. - If DEST exists and it is a directory, SOURCE will be moved into DEST - If DEST exists and it is a file, SOURCE must be a file and it will overwrite DEST If used with at least arguments as "rmv SOURCE... DIR" then DIR must be an existing directory and SOURCEs will be moved into it. EXAMPLES # alignment Usage example: /tmp> open music bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> rls f1 bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> rmv f1 f2 bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> rls f2 /tmp> open music bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> rtree |-- dir |-- f1 +-- f2 bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> rmv f1 f2 dir bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> rtree dir +-- dir |-- f1 +-- f2 SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help mv" for the local analogous.
rrm: COMMAND # alignment rrm - remove files and directories remotely SYNOPSIS # alignment rrm [FILE]... rrm [SHARING_LOCATION] [FILE]... SHARING_LOCATION must be specified if and only if not already connected to a remote sharing. In that case the connection will be established before execute the command, as "open SHARING_LOCATION" would do. Type "help open" for more information about SHARING_LOCATION format. DESCRIPTION # alignment Remove remote FILEs. If a FILE is a directory, it will be removed recursively. If a FILE does not exists, it will be ignored. This commands never prompts: essentially acts like unix's rm -rf. EXAMPLES # alignment Usage example: /tmp> open music bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> rls f1 f2 bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> rrm f2 bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> /tmp> open music bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> rtree |-- dir | |-- f1 | +-- f2 +-- f1 bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> rrm dir bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> rtree +-- f1 SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help rm" for the local analogous.
rexec: COMMAND # alignment rexec - execute an arbitrary command remotely SYNOPSIS # alignment rexec COMMAND :: COMMAND ::COMMAND rexec [SERVER_LOCATION] COMMAND :: [SERVER_LOCATION] COMMAND ::[SERVER_LOCATION] COMMAND SERVER_LOCATION must be specified if and only if not already connected to a remote server. In that case the connection will be established before execute the command, as "connect SERVER_LOCATION" would do. Type "help connect" for more information about SERVER_LOCATION format. DESCRIPTION # alignment THE SERVER REJECTS THIS COMMAND BY DEFAULT, UNLESS IT HAS BEEN MANUALLY ENABLED WITH THE SETTING "rexec=true" Executes an arbitrary COMMAND remotely. The COMMAND is executed via the shell and therefore allows all the shell features (e.g. variables, glob expansions, redirection). This might be useful for execute commands remotely, giving the client a kind of easy and plug-and-play shell. The command can be run either with "rexec COMMAND", ":: COMMAND" or "::COMMAND". EXAMPLES # alignment Usage example: /tmp> open music bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> rls f1 f2 bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> rexec touch f3 f1 f2 f3 bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> :: echo "hello" > f3 bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> ::cat f3 hello SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help exec" for the local analogous.
::: COMMAND # alignment rexec - execute an arbitrary command remotely SYNOPSIS # alignment rexec COMMAND :: COMMAND ::COMMAND rexec [SERVER_LOCATION] COMMAND :: [SERVER_LOCATION] COMMAND ::[SERVER_LOCATION] COMMAND SERVER_LOCATION must be specified if and only if not already connected to a remote server. In that case the connection will be established before execute the command, as "connect SERVER_LOCATION" would do. Type "help connect" for more information about SERVER_LOCATION format. DESCRIPTION # alignment THE SERVER REJECTS THIS COMMAND BY DEFAULT, UNLESS IT HAS BEEN MANUALLY ENABLED WITH THE SETTING "rexec=true" Executes an arbitrary COMMAND remotely. The COMMAND is executed via the shell and therefore allows all the shell features (e.g. variables, glob expansions, redirection). This might be useful for execute commands remotely, giving the client a kind of easy and plug-and-play shell. The command can be run either with "rexec COMMAND", ":: COMMAND" or "::COMMAND". EXAMPLES # alignment Usage example: /tmp> open music bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> rls f1 f2 bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> rexec touch f3 f1 f2 f3 bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> :: echo "hello" > f3 bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> ::cat f3 hello SEE ALSO # alignment Type "help exec" for the local analogous.
scan: COMMAND # alignment scan - scan the network for easyshare servers SYNOPSIS # alignment scan [OPTION]... s [OPTION]... DESCRIPTION # alignment Scan the network for easyshare server and reports the details of the sharings found. The discover is performed in broadcast in the network. The port on which the discover is performed is the one specified to es via -d port, or the default one if not specified. The scan time is two seconds unless it has been specified to es via -w seconds. Only details about the sharings are shown, unless -L is given. OPTIONS # alignment -L show more details of both servers and sharings -l show more details of sharings EXAMPLES # alignment Usage example: /tmp> scan alice-arch (192.168.1.105:12020) DIRECTORIES - shared - tmp bob-debian (192.168.1.185:12020) DIRECTORIES - music FILES - README.txt
s: COMMAND # alignment scan - scan the network for easyshare servers SYNOPSIS # alignment scan [OPTION]... s [OPTION]... DESCRIPTION # alignment Scan the network for easyshare server and reports the details of the sharings found. The discover is performed in broadcast in the network. The port on which the discover is performed is the one specified to es via -d port, or the default one if not specified. The scan time is two seconds unless it has been specified to es via -w seconds. Only details about the sharings are shown, unless -L is given. OPTIONS # alignment -L show more details of both servers and sharings -l show more details of sharings EXAMPLES # alignment Usage example: /tmp> scan alice-arch (192.168.1.105:12020) DIRECTORIES - shared - tmp bob-debian (192.168.1.185:12020) DIRECTORIES - music FILES - README.txt
connect: COMMAND # alignment connect - connect to a remote server SYNOPSIS # alignment connect SERVER_LOCATION DESCRIPTION # alignment Connect to a remote server whose location is specified by SERVER_LOCATION. SERVER_LOCATION has the following syntax: <server_name> or <address>[:<port>] See the section EXAMPLES for more examples about SERVER_LOCATION. The following rules are applied for establish a connection: 1. If SERVER_LOCATION is a valid <server_name> (e.g. alice-arch), a discover is performed for figure out which port the server is bound to. 2. If SERVER_LOCATION has the form <address> (e.g. 192.168.1.105), the connection will be tried to be established directly to the server at the the default port. If the attempt fails, a discover is performed for figure out which port the server is really bound to and another attempt is done. 3. If SERVER_LOCATION has the form <address>:<port> (e.g, 182.168.1.106:22020), the connection will be established directly. The discover, if involved (1. and 2.), is performed on the port specified to eswith -d port for the time specified with -w seconds (default is two seconds). Note that connect is not necessary if you want to directly open a sharing, you can use open which automatically will establish the connection with the server as connect would do. There might be cases in which use connect is still required, for example for execute server commands (i.e. info, ping, list, rexec) which are not related to any sharings (you can use those commands if connected to a sharing, by the way). When possible, using "connect <server_name>" (1.) is more immediate and human friendly compared to specify the address and eventually the port of the server (2. and 3.). There are cases in which specify the address and the port of the server (3.) is necessary, for example when the discover can't be performed because the server is not on the same network of the client (e.g. behind a NAT). If already connected to a server, a successful connect execution to another server automatically closes the current connection. Remember that connect establish the connection with the server, but do not place you inside any server's sharing. Use open for that. EXAMPLES # alignment Usage example: 1. Connection by server name (discover) /tmp> connect alice-arch alice-arch - /tmp> list DIRECTORIES - shared - tmp 2. Connection by address (direct attempt, discover if fails) /tmp> connect 192.168.1.105 alice-arch - /tmp> 3. Connection by address and port (direct) /tmp> connect 89.1.2.84:22020 eve-kali - /tmp> SEE ALSO # alignment disconnect>, open
disconnect: COMMAND # alignment disconnect - disconnect from a remote server SYNOPSIS # alignment disconnect DESCRIPTION # alignment Disconnect from the remote server to which the connection is established. While this command is the counterpart of connect, it can be used to close connections opened in other ways (i.e. with open). This differs from close which closes only the currently opened sharing without closing the connection. EXAMPLES # alignment Usage example: /tmp> connect alice-arch alice-arch - /tmp> disconnect /tmp> connect SEE ALSO # alignment connect, close
open: COMMAND # alignment open - open a remote sharing (eventually discovering it) SYNOPSIS # alignment open SHARING_LOCATION DESCRIPTION # alignment Open a sharing whose location is specified by SHARING_LOCATION SHARING_LOCATION has the following syntax: <sharing_name>[@<server_name>|<address>[:<port>]] See the section EXAMPLES for more examples about SHARING_LOCATION. The following rules are applied for establish a connection: 1. If SHARING_LOCATION is a valid <sharing_name> (e.g. shared), a discover is performed for figure out to which server the sharing belongs to. 2. If SHARING_LOCATION has the form <sharing_name>@<server_name>[:port] (e.g. shared@alice-arch) a discover is performed as well as in case 1. and the <server_name> and the <port> act only as a filter (i.e. the connection won't be established if they don't match). 3. If SHARING_LOCATION has the form <sharing_name>@<address> (e.g. shared@192.168.1.105) the connection will be tried to be established directly to the server at the default port. If the attempt fails, a discover is performed for figure out which port the server is really bound to and another attempt is done. 4. If SHARING_LOCATION has the form <sharing_name>@<address>:<port> (e.g. shared@192.168.1.105:12020) the connection will be established directly. The discover, if involved (1., 2. and 3.), is performed on the port specified to es with -d port for the time specified with -w seconds (default is two seconds). Note that connect is not necessary if you want to directly open a sharing, you can use open which automatically will establish the connection with the server as connect would do. When possible, using the server name (1., 2. and 3.) is more immediate and human friendly compared to specify the address and eventually the port of the server (4.). There are cases in which specify the address and the port of the server (4.) is necessary, for example when the discover can't be performed because the server is not on the same network of the client (e.g. behind a NAT). If the sharing described by SHARING_LOCATION is found within the sharings of the server to which the connection is already established, it will be obviously opened without perform any kind of discover or new connection. If already connected to a server and/or a sharing, a successful open execution to another server automatically closes the current connection. If, for some reason, there is more than a sharing with the same name on the same network, open will try to connect to the one that is discovered first (in general it's unpredictable which will be). If you need a deterministic (and more safe) approach, consider using scan for discover the server manually (eventually followed by a consecutive info call for fetch more accurate details such as SSL certificate) then invoke open specifying the server details too (i.e. server name or address and port). In general, open doesn't require you to use connect before; the connection will be created for you automatically. EXAMPLES # alignment Usage example: 1. Connection by sharing name (while connected) /tmp> connect alice-arch alice-arch - /tmp> open temp alice-arch.temp:/ - /tmp> rls f1 f2 1. Connection by sharing name (discover) /tmp> open temp alice-arch.temp:/ - /tmp> rls f1 f2 2. Connection by sharing name with server name filter (discover) /tmp> open temp@alice-arch alice-arch.temp:/ - /tmp> 3. Connection by sharing name with address (attempt direct, discover if fails) /tmp> open temp@alice-arch alice-arch.temp:/ - /tmp> 4. Connection by sharing name with address and port (direct) /tmp> open temp@192.168.1.105:12020 alice-arch.temp:/ - /tmp> SEE ALSO # alignment close>, connect
o: COMMAND # alignment open - open a remote sharing (eventually discovering it) SYNOPSIS # alignment open SHARING_LOCATION DESCRIPTION # alignment Open a sharing whose location is specified by SHARING_LOCATION SHARING_LOCATION has the following syntax: <sharing_name>[@<server_name>|<address>[:<port>]] See the section EXAMPLES for more examples about SHARING_LOCATION. The following rules are applied for establish a connection: 1. If SHARING_LOCATION is a valid <sharing_name> (e.g. shared), a discover is performed for figure out to which server the sharing belongs to. 2. If SHARING_LOCATION has the form <sharing_name>@<server_name>[:port] (e.g. shared@alice-arch) a discover is performed as well as in case 1. and the <server_name> and the <port> act only as a filter (i.e. the connection won't be established if they don't match). 3. If SHARING_LOCATION has the form <sharing_name>@<address> (e.g. shared@192.168.1.105) the connection will be tried to be established directly to the server at the default port. If the attempt fails, a discover is performed for figure out which port the server is really bound to and another attempt is done. 4. If SHARING_LOCATION has the form <sharing_name>@<address>:<port> (e.g. shared@192.168.1.105:12020) the connection will be established directly. The discover, if involved (1., 2. and 3.), is performed on the port specified to es with -d port for the time specified with -w seconds (default is two seconds). Note that connect is not necessary if you want to directly open a sharing, you can use open which automatically will establish the connection with the server as connect would do. When possible, using the server name (1., 2. and 3.) is more immediate and human friendly compared to specify the address and eventually the port of the server (4.). There are cases in which specify the address and the port of the server (4.) is necessary, for example when the discover can't be performed because the server is not on the same network of the client (e.g. behind a NAT). If the sharing described by SHARING_LOCATION is found within the sharings of the server to which the connection is already established, it will be obviously opened without perform any kind of discover or new connection. If already connected to a server and/or a sharing, a successful open execution to another server automatically closes the current connection. If, for some reason, there is more than a sharing with the same name on the same network, open will try to connect to the one that is discovered first (in general it's unpredictable which will be). If you need a deterministic (and more safe) approach, consider using scan for discover the server manually (eventually followed by a consecutive info call for fetch more accurate details such as SSL certificate) then invoke open specifying the server details too (i.e. server name or address and port). In general, open doesn't require you to use connect before; the connection will be created for you automatically. EXAMPLES # alignment Usage example: 1. Connection by sharing name (while connected) /tmp> connect alice-arch alice-arch - /tmp> open temp alice-arch.temp:/ - /tmp> rls f1 f2 1. Connection by sharing name (discover) /tmp> open temp alice-arch.temp:/ - /tmp> rls f1 f2 2. Connection by sharing name with server name filter (discover) /tmp> open temp@alice-arch alice-arch.temp:/ - /tmp> 3. Connection by sharing name with address (attempt direct, discover if fails) /tmp> open temp@alice-arch alice-arch.temp:/ - /tmp> 4. Connection by sharing name with address and port (direct) /tmp> open temp@192.168.1.105:12020 alice-arch.temp:/ - /tmp> SEE ALSO # alignment close>, connect
close: COMMAND # alignment close - close the remote sharing SYNOPSIS # alignment close DESCRIPTION # alignment Close the currently opened sharing. If the sharing connection has been created directly with open instead of connect and then open, than the server connection is closed too (for symmetry). EXAMPLES # alignment Usage example: 1. Close sharing connection only /tmp> connect alice-arch alice-arch - /tmp> open shared alice-arch.shared:/ - /tmp> close alice-arch - /tmp> close 2. Close both sharing and server connection /tmp> open music bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> close /tmp> SEE ALSO # alignment open, disconnect
c: COMMAND # alignment close - close the remote sharing SYNOPSIS # alignment close DESCRIPTION # alignment Close the currently opened sharing. If the sharing connection has been created directly with open instead of connect and then open, than the server connection is closed too (for symmetry). EXAMPLES # alignment Usage example: 1. Close sharing connection only /tmp> connect alice-arch alice-arch - /tmp> open shared alice-arch.shared:/ - /tmp> close alice-arch - /tmp> close 2. Close both sharing and server connection /tmp> open music bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> close /tmp> SEE ALSO # alignment open, disconnect
list: COMMAND # alignment list - list the sharings of the remote server SYNOPSIS # alignment list [OPTION]... list [SERVER_LOCATION] [OPTION]... SERVER_LOCATION must be specified if and only if not already connected to a remote server. In that case the connection will be established before execute the command, as "connect SERVER_LOCATION" would do. Type "help connect" for more information about SERVER_LOCATION format. DESCRIPTION # alignment List the sharings of the remote server to which the connection is established. OPTIONS # alignment -l show more details of sharings EXAMPLES # alignment Usage example: /tmp> connect alice-arch alice-arch - /tmp> list DIRECTORIES - shared - tmp /tmp> open music bob-debian.music:/ - /tmp> list DIRECTORIES - music FILES - README.txt
info: COMMAND # alignment info - show information about the remote server SYNOPSIS # alignment info [OPTION]... info [SERVER_LOCATION] [OPTION]... SERVER_LOCATION must be specified if and only if not already connected to a remote server. In that case the connection will be established before execute the command, as "connect SERVER_LOCATION" would do. Type "help connect" for more information about SERVER_LOCATION format. DESCRIPTION # alignment Show information of the remote server to which the connection is established. The reported information are: - Server name - Server ip - Server port - Server discover port - Authentication enabled/disabled - SSL enabled/disabled - SSL certificate info (if enabled) - Sharings OPTIONS # alignment -l show more details of sharings EXAMPLES # alignment Usage example: /tmp> connect alice-arch alice-arch - /tmp> info ================================ SERVER INFO Name: alice-arch IP: 192.168.1.105 Port: 12020 Discoverable: True Discover Port: 12019 Auth: False SSL: True ================================ SSL CERTIFICATE Common name: 192.168.1.105 Organization: Acme Corporation Organization Unit: Acme Corporation Email: acme@gmail.com Locality: Los Angeles State: Los Angeles Country: US Valid From: Apr 24 21:29:46 2020 GMT Valid To: Apr 24 21:29:46 2021 GMT Issuer: 192.168.1.105, Acme Corporation Signing: self signed ================================ SHARINGS DIRECTORIES - tmp ================================
i: COMMAND # alignment info - show information about the remote server SYNOPSIS # alignment info [OPTION]... info [SERVER_LOCATION] [OPTION]... SERVER_LOCATION must be specified if and only if not already connected to a remote server. In that case the connection will be established before execute the command, as "connect SERVER_LOCATION" would do. Type "help connect" for more information about SERVER_LOCATION format. DESCRIPTION # alignment Show information of the remote server to which the connection is established. The reported information are: - Server name - Server ip - Server port - Server discover port - Authentication enabled/disabled - SSL enabled/disabled - SSL certificate info (if enabled) - Sharings OPTIONS # alignment -l show more details of sharings EXAMPLES # alignment Usage example: /tmp> connect alice-arch alice-arch - /tmp> info ================================ SERVER INFO Name: alice-arch IP: 192.168.1.105 Port: 12020 Discoverable: True Discover Port: 12019 Auth: False SSL: True ================================ SSL CERTIFICATE Common name: 192.168.1.105 Organization: Acme Corporation Organization Unit: Acme Corporation Email: acme@gmail.com Locality: Los Angeles State: Los Angeles Country: US Valid From: Apr 24 21:29:46 2020 GMT Valid To: Apr 24 21:29:46 2021 GMT Issuer: 192.168.1.105, Acme Corporation Signing: self signed ================================ SHARINGS DIRECTORIES - tmp ================================
ping: COMMAND # alignment ping - test the connection with the remote server SYNOPSIS # alignment ping [OPTION]... ping [SERVER_LOCATION] [OPTION]... SERVER_LOCATION must be specified if and only if not already connected to a remote server. In that case the connection will be established before execute the command, as "connect SERVER_LOCATION" would do. Type "help connect" for more information about SERVER_LOCATION format. DESCRIPTION # alignment Test the connectivity with the server by sending an application-level message. OPTIONS # alignment -c, --count count stop after count messages EXAMPLES # alignment Usage example: /tmp> connect alice-arch alice-arch - /tmp> ping [1] PONG from alice-arch (192.168.1.105:12020) | time=5.1ms [2] PONG from alice-arch (192.168.1.105:12020) | time=0.9ms ... /tmp> ping bob-debian -c 1 [1] PONG from bob-debian (192.168.1.185:12020) | time=9.3ms /tmp> ping 192.168.1.185 -c 1 [1] PONG from bob-debian (192.168.1.185:12020) | time=10.3ms
